content: @Jonathan Chasteen @Bawer Dagdeviren :wave: and welcome

Thank you for extending the invitation

maybe there are others that joined after the post (unsure), new members feel free to introduce yourself and let us know if from reading the blog post and related material you have an idea about what more or less the working group does
one quick thing that I can tell you is that on #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts new topics are automatically created, requesting that we discuss those issues and prioritize them
as an example check out #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts > I-prioritize #76507 #[link_section] is unsound on Harvard a… for instance of what usually happens
Of course if you have any questions feel free to ask :)

Yes. For now everything is clear.
cool :+1:
one important thing that we do is to have all I-prioritize issues prioritized
basically https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3AI-prioritize
and there should be one topic per each of those issues on #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts
there may be some which we already have decided a priority but no one has actually added the label
I usually go over all these stuff on wednesday's
we have two zulip groups that are pinged when some stuff happens
@Jonathan Chasteen @Bawer Dagdeviren @Stu @DJ Carpenter @am-1t @Fred Østrem @Camelid @Mason Stallmo do you all want to be added to both groups?
talking about @*WG-prioritization* and @*WG-prioritization/alerts*
Yes please
so once those groups are mentioned you get a notification
yes please
Yes please :+1:
Sure :+1:
I've added all of you, but feel free to ask to be removed if it bothers, the idea of having groups like these is as a way of helping, not as a way of bothering so do not hesitate to ask to be removed
for instance I do not belong to the alerts one because I prefer to check new issues by myself and not to be notified

to summarise, the general process is:

  • an issue gets marked by a triagist / any random person as I-prioritize, and a thread is automatically created in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts
  • WG members look at the issue and discuss what priority it deserves
  • after there is sufficient consensus (many people agree to the same priority or after waiting for roughly a day) the issue is marked with the corresponding priority label (p-*) with a note linking to the thread where it was discussed and I-prioritize is removed
  • P-critical / P-high issues make their way to the compiler team meetings which happens every Thursday (so you'll see more activity here on Wednesdays)

As newcomers to the group you might find it tricky to assess the priority, but free to voice your opinion about an issue :smile: (there's more on our process written down somewhere :stuck_out_tongue: )
Yes please!
Everything seemed clear bout what the wg does from the blog post. Is there anything else that would be helpful to know that wasn’t contained in that post?
haven't read the blogpost yet

Mason Stallmo said:

Everything seemed clear bout what the wg does from the blog post. Is there anything else that would be helpful to know that wasn’t contained in that post?

I guess we will find out as we go
I'm going to add on top of what @DPC has said that another important thing is to prepare the agenda for the meeting (I think that was clear on the blog post)

so we do two main things, one is discover critical issues and high priority regressions and also curate and the other one is that accommodate the agenda for the compiler meeting, most of the things to be discussed are collectively chosen, but we play an important role in the definition of certain items and explanation of the agenda
How is it possible to contribute in a sane way without being very skilled/knowledgable in the details of the issues?

a couple things that make sense for any issue:

  • how many people does it affect?
  • is it a regression? from when?
  • how much of an effect does it have?
if you can find that information, it's very helpful even if you don't know what priority it should be

how many people does it affect?

normally this involves finding an MCVE (or adding E-needs-mcve to ask the community to do it)
sometimes bugs affect major crates, and then it's almost always a P-high or P-critical
e.g. https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/75100 or https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/76270
:+1: to what Joshua Nelson has said
about regressions in particular
once we have an MCVE, you may want to use it in godbolt to try it out in old Rust versions
and find out if the issue is something that never worked
or if it's a regression and when the thing started to fail
ooh godbolt is a good idea, I never thought of that :laughing: normally I use cargo-bisect-rustc
also, if we find a recent regression ... exactly :)
also use cargo-bisect-rustc

Joshua Nelson said:

ooh godbolt is a good idea, I never thought of that :laughing: normally I use cargo-bisect-rustc

cargo-bisect-rustc is only useful with recent regressions
but after we identified a recent regression cargo-bisect-rustc will tell us where has the code regressed by identified the commit in the compiler that has introduced the regression
that works if the regressions is "recent"
would work for nightly and beta regressions for sure which are important ones to identify
for stable regressions it depends how old it is
you need both
godbolt is to find out how many versions it's affecting, bisect is to find out which was last nightly where it worked and thus narrow down to a pr that introduced the bug or a set of PRs

Bawer Dagdeviren said:

How is it possible to contribute in a sane way without being very skilled/knowledgable in the details of the issues?

On top of all great suggestions above, I'd add that I agree with you that it is not always easy to assess the priority of an issue without context. Sometimes I fail to make an educated assessment, sometimes it's stuff really above my head and I just try to give an opinion based on few assumptions, which are then adjusted by someone that know better than me (and it's great because then I learn a little something).

Sometimes we don't know either and we ask "outside". And sometimes we apply the tag I-nominated to ensure that the compiler team has a specific discussion during their meeting on this issue.
Thanks! I am sure it will all slowly fall into place once I start doing the practical side of this work.
(I'm a little surprised no issues have popped up in alerts during the discussion :laughing: )
haha

Yeah, please add me to both.
I think I’ve got a pretty good idea about how the wg operates, although I think seeing the process in action will be most helpful. For other new members who may be unsure how this group fits into the bigger picture https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/ was very enlightening to me.
I’ve got some pretty extensive experience with GitHub infra and would be happy to contribute to the bot on top of following up with alerts
The bot in question is triagebot, and we have a couple of open issues for implementing a few more features to it
See https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues

going to follow the procedure stated in https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html

  • Prioritization WG: you will get some privileges on the rust-lang/rust repo, namely being able to triage issues (add labels etc...) and invoke some useful @rustbot commands such as @rustbot ping.

Hi, thanks for adding me to this wg! I have some questions of labeling:

  1. When does rust-bot label an issue as I-prioritize?
  2. May I label an issue as I-prioritize?
  3. Should we add P- labels to all unclosed issues?
Where is the Zulip stream of cleanup crew team? I want to ask someone about the cleanup work.

The cleanup crew does not have a zulip stream because it's just a "Notification group".
But you can ask here I guess or read the rust forge

For the other questions:

  1. I don't really know either, but on regression-from-* labels, just manually assigned by anyone, or if any I- label is assigned (I think)
  2. Yes, you can do it, if you are in the rust organization/team.
  3. No, not every issue needs a Priority.
Thanks!

1. When does rust-bot label an issue as I-prioritize?

@tamuhey FYI, the "autolabel thing" is configured here, in the triagebot.toml file. It assigns I-prioritize for any issue that's a regression or a soundness bug, if it hasn't already been prioritized yet (or it concerns another team, or it's a nightly-only bug)

1. May I label an issue as I-prioritize?

Usually that's done by the Triage WG when they run through the list of issues and find that a particular issue might be important enough to be brought up for discussion
:+1: but I'd encourage anyone to add I-prioritize if you consider that the issue may be important and still doesn't have a P label
in my opinion it should be like ... if you see an issue that you think feels like P-high or P-critical go ahead and add I-prioritize
if you're sure that the issue is P-low or P-medium maybe do not even bother to tag it as I-prioritize

Any compiler bug that requires attention, I'd say, even if you're not sure that it will be P-high or above. IMO we have enough people here to be able to afford prioritizing a few more issues than necessary
not just triage-wg but others as well, anyone who wants attention on an issue and is within the "rust umbrella" can do so
@Sayan :wave:
Sayan wrote to me in private mentioning that they'll be interested in participating in the group
Welcome o/
Heya, everyone! Thanks for letting me be a part of this WG!
